titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to "A brief history of medicine" short subject film, circa 1969 RL.11348
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-11-01 16:23:22 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: A brief history of medicine short subject film

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Wake Forest University. School of Medicine

did.abstract: Short subject film whose sequence of still images encapsulates the evolution of medical knowledge and practices from Neolithic times to the 20th century. The style is sixties psychedelic, with fast-moving sequences and vivid colors. The still images consist of historical scenes, procedures, and individuals significant to the history of medicine, chiefly Western, but there are a few images from Eastern practices. The only sound is music from "Mass in F Minor" by the Electric Prunes rock group (1968). Produced by staff in the Audio Visual Resources at the School of Medicine at Wake Forest University for educational purposes as well as for photographic research. Although the original 16 mm film is restricted, there are two DVD use copies for viewing. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Wake Forest University School of Medicine, formerly the Bowman Gray School of Medicine, was founded in 1902 and is based in Winston-Salem at Wake Forest University.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: However, original media is closed to use. Viewing copies exist in the collection.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The short subject film, "A brief history of medicine," was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a transfer in 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], "A brief history of medicine" short subject film, circa 1969, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

unittitle.label: Collection
unittitle.extref: "The history of Western medicine" video recording, 1997

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Short subject film whose sequence of still images encapsulates the evolution of medical knowledge and practices from Neolithic times to the 20th century. The style is sixties psychedelic, with fast-moving sequences and vivid colors. The still images consist of historical scenes, procedures, and individuals significant to the history of medicine, chiefly Western, but there are a few images from Eastern practices. The only sound is music from "Mass in F Minor" by the Electric Prunes rock group (1968). Produced by staff in the Audio Visual Resources at the School of Medicine at Wake Forest University for educational purposes as well as for photographic research. Although the original 16 mm film is restricted, there are two DVD use copies for viewing. Acquired as part of the History of Medicine Collections at Duke University.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: 16 mm film on 5 inch reel; TRT (total running time) of DVD use copy recording: 00:03:27 (3 minutes, 27 seconds).

did.unittitle: 16 mm color film on 5 inch reel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The film exhibits some color, soundtrack, and surface deterioration; total running time on DVD viewing copies 3 minutes, 27 seconds.
